title: Peer Pressure Can Be Good
sub_head: Every summer, my exercise buddies set an example of self-improvement.
body:
Summer is when my exercise group leads something called its Father Time Challenge. FTC, as we know it, is a series of runs and exercises of varying distance and difficulty. We complete it together over a hilly course each Saturday morning throughout July.
The challenges vary weekly, but not from year to year. That way we can see where we’ve improved and, more often, where we still need improvement. There’s one catch: Each workout must be completed in under an hour. It’s doable, but far from easy.
A banquet is held in August to honor the fortunate, fleet-footed few among us who posted qualifying times for each workout. T-shirts are designed and awarded—our version of the Masters Green Jacket—to these garlanded guests, who wear them proudly throughout the year.
It’s the distance-running FTC segments I least enjoy. They give me time to think, though, if only to forget the burning in my lungs. Here’s what occurred to me one Saturday: “Don’t give in to peer pressure”—that bankable adage I grew up believing—is wrong, or at least incomplete. The lesson should be: If bad peers are applying untoward pressure, find better peers. They’re out there.
This struck me as I saw Jed, a larger man than I, fly past me on a grueling uphill run. Departing alongside him was self-delusion that guys like me, nobody’s bantamweight, can’t run with the swift. I can find a higher gear if I follow Jed’s example and dig a little deeper.
